sites.name: Ciudad de las Artes y las Ciencias
sites.description: The City of Arts and Sciences is a cultural and architectural complex designed by Santiago Calatrava and Félix Candela. It features futuristic buildings housing a science museum, planetarium, IMAX cinema, aquarium, opera house, and landscaped areas. The striking white structures have become iconic symbols of Valencia's modern identity.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Summer brings extended hours and increased visitors. Spring and autumn offer pleasant temperatures and fewer crowds. Winter provides clear skies for photography. Combined tickets available for multiple venues. The complex is beautiful both day and night with special lighting after dark.
sites.booking_tips: Online tickets strongly recommended. Combined tickets offer savings for multiple venues. Photography permitted in most areas. Comfortable walking shoes essential. Cafe and restaurant options available on-site. Allow at least half a day to visit multiple buildings.

sites.name: Mercado Central
sites.description: Valencia's Central Market is one of Europe's largest fresh food markets, housed in a stunning modernist building. The market features over 1,000 stalls selling fresh produce, seafood, meats, cheeses, and local specialties. The building itself is an architectural gem with beautiful stained glass and tilework.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open Monday-Saturday mornings. Closed Sundays. Early morning provides the freshest products and local atmosphere. Summer brings vibrant produce selections. Winter offers seasonal specialties. The market is busiest on Saturdays and just before Spanish holidays.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Arrive early for the best experience. Photography permitted. Food tours available with local guides. Located in historic center near other attractions. Many vendors offer samples and small tapas.

sites.name: Catedral de Valencia
sites.description: Valencia Cathedral is a Gothic masterpiece with elements from various architectural periods. The cathedral houses what is claimed to be the Holy Grail, as well as paintings by Goya and other Spanish masters. Its distinctive bell tower, the Miguelete, offers panoramic views of the city.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Religious services may affect tourist access. Summer brings increased visitors. Winter offers more peaceful atmosphere. Holy Week (Semana Santa) brings special ceremonies and limited access. The cathedral's interior provides relief from extreme weather.
sites.booking_tips: Audio guides available in multiple languages. Tower access requires separate ticket. Photography permitted in most areas. Modest dress required. Located in historic center. Combined tickets with other religious sites available.

sites.name: Lonja de la Seda
sites.description: The Silk Exchange is a masterpiece of Gothic civil architecture and a UNESCO World Heritage site. Built between 1482 and 1548, it symbolizes Valencia's golden age as a Mediterranean trading power. The main hall features twisted columns that resemble palm trees, and the building showcases beautiful stonework and gargoyles.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Summer brings increased visitors. Winter offers more peaceful atmosphere. The building's stone interior stays cool even during hot summer days.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Audio guides available. Photography permitted. Located opposite Central Market. Combined tickets with other historic sites available. Guided tours offer historical context.

sites.name: Jardín del Turia
sites.description: The Turia Gardens are a 9-kilometer green belt created in the former riverbed of the Turia River after it was diverted following devastating floods. The park features sports areas, playgrounds, cycling paths, fountains, and landscaped gardens. It connects many of Valencia's major attractions and serves as the city's green lung.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Spring brings blooming flowers and pleasant temperatures. Summer mornings and evenings most comfortable. Autumn offers beautiful colors. Winter provides clear skies and sparse crowds. The park hosts various festivals and events throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Bicycle and scooter rentals available. Multiple access points throughout the city. Comfortable walking shoes recommended. Connects major attractions including City of Arts and Sciences. Water fountains available throughout.

sites.name: Playa de la Malvarrosa
sites.description: Malvarrosa Beach is Valencia's main urban beach, featuring golden sand and a vibrant promenade lined with restaurants and bars. The beach is well-equipped with facilities and offers a perfect spot to relax after sightseeing. Its proximity to the city center makes it easily accessible by public transport.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Summer brings crowded beaches and warm water. Spring and autumn offer pleasant temperatures with fewer crowds. Winter provides peaceful walks along the promenade. Beach services reduced outside summer season. The promenade restaurants serve authentic paella year-round.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Beach umbrellas and chairs available for rent in summer. Public transportation available from city center. Beachfront restaurants popular for paella – reservations recommended. Water sports equipment rentals available in summer.

sites.name: Bioparc Valencia
sites.description: Bioparc Valencia is an immersive zoo designed with the concept of 'zoo-immersion,' where barriers are hidden and animals live in recreated natural habitats. The park focuses on African ecosystems and features a wide range of species in naturalistic settings. The design emphasizes conservation and education.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Mornings offer more active animals. Summer brings extended hours but hot temperatures. Spring and autumn provide ideal visiting conditions. Winter offers fewer crowds. Feeding times and demonstrations vary seasonally.
sites.booking_tips: Online tickets recommended. Plan around animal feeding times. Photography permitted. Comfortable walking shoes essential. Located in Turia Gardens with good public transport. Restaurant and cafe options available on-site.

sites.name: Barrio del Carmen
sites.description: El Carmen is Valencia's historic bohemian quarter, featuring narrow medieval streets, colorful buildings, and vibrant street art. The neighborhood blends historical architecture with trendy bars, restaurants, and shops. By day, it offers cultural sites and shops; by night, it transforms into the center of Valencia's nightlife.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Summer evenings bring outdoor dining and street performers. Spring and autumn offer pleasant temperatures. Winter brings holiday decorations. The narrow streets provide shade during hot days. Special events and festivals throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Guided walking tours available. Comfortable walking shoes essential. Many restaurants and tapas bars to explore. Street performers common in good weather. Located in the heart of Valencia's old town.

sites.name: Museo de Bellas Artes
sites.description: The Museum of Fine Arts is one of Spain's most important art galleries, housed in a former seminary. The collection focuses on Valencian painters, particularly works by Sorolla, Ribera, and Velázquez. The building itself is architecturally significant, with beautiful courtyards and galleries.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Free entry. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Summer brings extended hours. The museum's central location makes it easily accessible in any weather.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Audio guides available. Guided tours offer deeper insights. Photography permitted in most areas without flash. Located near Turia Gardens. Closed on Mondays.

sites.name: Albufera Natural Park
sites.description: Albufera is a freshwater lagoon and estuary with surrounding wetlands and rice fields just south of Valencia. This natural park is home to diverse bird species and traditional fishing communities. The area is famous for being the birthplace of paella and offers boat tours, birdwatching, and beautiful sunsets.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Spring brings bird migrations and rice planting. Summer offers boat trips and beach access. Autumn features rice harvests and gastronomy events. Winter provides excellent birdwatching opportunities with fewer tourists. Sunset boat trips particularly beautiful year-round.
sites.booking_tips: Boat tours can be booked on-site. Public buses available from Valencia. Guided birdwatching tours available. Photography opportunities abundant. Traditional restaurants in El Palmar village. Combine with beach visit to El Saler.

sites.name: Torres de Serranos
sites.description: The Serranos Towers are one of the twelve gates that formed part of the ancient city wall of Valencia. Built in the 14th century in Gothic style, they served as both defensive structures and ceremonial entrances to the city. Today, they offer panoramic views of the historic center and Turia Gardens.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Summer afternoons bring excellent lighting for photography. Spring and autumn offer pleasant temperatures. Winter provides clearer views and fewer crowds. The towers host special events during city festivals.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Small entrance fee. Photography permitted. Comfortable shoes recommended for stairs. Located at the edge of the historic center. Free entry on Sundays.

sites.name: Plaza de la Virgen
sites.description: Plaza de la Virgen is the historic heart of Valencia, situated where the Roman forum once stood. The square is surrounded by the Cathedral, Basilica, and Palace of the Generalitat. A central fountain represents the Turia River and its irrigation channels. The square hosts many traditional events and religious festivities.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. Summer evenings bring outdoor dining and street performers. Spring features religious processions during Holy Week. The Water Tribunal meets every Thursday at noon year-round. Winter brings holiday decorations and fewer tourists.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Street performers common in good weather. Many cafes with outdoor seating. Located near major attractions. Important venue during Las Fallas festival. Water Tribunal (UNESCO Heritage) meets Thursdays at noon.

sites.name: Oceanogràfic
sites.description: The Oceanogràfic is Europe's largest aquarium, part of the City of Arts and Sciences complex. Designed by Félix Candela, it houses over 45,000 marine creatures representing 500 species in different habitats. The innovative architecture mimics various marine environments, with underwater tunnels and viewing areas.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Less crowded on weekday mornings. Summer brings peak tourist numbers. Winter offers a more relaxed experience. Special night openings during summer months. Dolphin shows and feeding times scheduled throughout the day.
sites.booking_tips: Online tickets strongly recommended. Combined tickets available with other City of Arts and Sciences venues. Photography permitted. Plan around feeding times and shows. Restaurant with underwater views available. Allow at least 3 hours for visit.

sites.name: Museo Fallero
sites.description: The Fallas Museum showcases the artistic ninots (figures) that have been saved from burning during the annual Fallas festival. These satirical sculptures represent the best of each year's festivities. The museum offers insight into Valencia's most important cultural celebration and its evolution over time.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round. Busiest during Fallas festival in March. Summer brings increased tourists. Winter offers quieter visits. New ninots added annually after March festival. The museum provides context for visitors unfamiliar with Fallas traditions.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Small entrance fee. Photography permitted. Located away from city center – public transport available. Combined tickets with other museums available. Informational videos in multiple languages.

sites.name: Plaza del Ayuntamiento
sites.description: The Town Hall Square is Valencia's main civic space, featuring the impressive city hall building, post office, and other architectural landmarks. The large rectangular plaza hosts major events, including the daily mascletà fireworks during Fallas festival. Surrounded by shops and cafes, it serves as a central meeting point.
sites.seasonal_notes: Accessible year-round. March brings daily Fallas events and large crowds. Summer features outdoor dining and evening ambiance. Winter hosts holiday markets and decorations. The square is the focal point for many city celebrations throughout the year.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required. Central location makes it easy to access. Many restaurants and shops surrounding. Major transportation hub. Spectacular during Fallas festival in March. City Hall balcony viewable during certain hours.

sites.name: IVAM (Instituto Valenciano de Arte Moderno)
sites.description: The Valencian Institute of Modern Art is a leading contemporary art museum featuring works by Spanish and international artists. The collection includes pieces by Julio González, Pablo Picasso, and Alexander Calder, among others. The building itself is a modern architectural landmark with rotating exhibitions.
sites.seasonal_notes: Open year-round with climate-controlled galleries. Less crowded on weekday afternoons. Special exhibitions rotate seasonally. Summer brings extended hours. Free entry on Sundays and for certain groups.
sites.booking_tips: No booking required for general access. Audio guides available. Photography permitted in most areas without flash. Located near historic center. Museum café offers pleasant outdoor seating. Combined tickets with other museums available.
